etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Baxter (1615–1691), ejected minister and religious writer. From classical Latin procāc-, procāx forward, bold, impudent, frivolous (from procāre to ask, demand + -āx, suffix forming adjectives) + -ious

definitions: Insolent or arrogant in attitude or tone; forward, cheeky; provocative.
